ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

DATA PROTECTION LEGISLATION


    1. Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether his Ministry will consider introducing data protection legislation to ensure that personal data submitted electronically will not be sold or otherwise used for improper purposes, without the knowledge and permission of the data subjects.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Tang Guan Seng) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker Sir, although Singapore does not have a blanket law to cover protection of personal data, we do have laws that cover specific areas where abuse of personal data may occur. For example, communication and electronic data are protected under the various provisions of the Telecommunication Authority of Singapore Act and the Computer Misuse Act, while the Banking Act prevents disclosure of information on individual bank accounts.

    Personal data obtained by the Government are protected through the Official Secrets Act, the Statutory Boards and Government Companies (Protection of Secrecy) Act, and the Statistics Act.

    The National Computer Board, in conjunction with the relevant agencies, is reviewing the coverage of existing laws in the face of a changing global environment. One present area of focus is electronic commerce.

    The multi-agency Electronic Commerce Policy Committee is reviewing existing laws to ensure that there is adequate protection for transacting parties in electronic commerce. The review is progressing hand in hand with development of technical solutions to provide protection for personal data. The combined use of digital certificates, digital signatures and encryption keys in Singapore's electronic commerce framework will enhance security by allowing transacting parties to be identified and verified, as well as allow information to be decrypted only by authorised parties.

If necessary, we will not hesitate to amend existing laws or propose new ones, so as to support electronic commerce.

INVESTMENT ALLOWANCE SCHEME
(Extension to hiring of equipment and machinery)


    2. Dr Teo Ho Pin asked the Minister for National Development whether his Ministry will consider extending the Investment Allowance Scheme to locally-owned construction firms which hire equipment and machinery (as approved by the Construction Industry Development Board) so as to encourage higher level of mechanisation in the construction industry.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Koo Tsai Kee) (for the Minister for National Development): Sir, the objective of the Investment Allowance Scheme is to encourage contractors to achieve a higher level of mechanisation and productivity by investing in machinery and equipment.

    Hiring is not the same as investing. Extending the scheme to hiring of equipment and machinery will only help contractors to reduce their immediate cost of operations. For the good of the industry, contractors should be forward looking and plan for the long term through long-term investments in machinery and equipment. Therefore, my Ministry does not see the need to extend the Investment Allowance Scheme to the hiring of equipment and machinery.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS
(Shortening of development time)


    3. Dr Teo Ho Pin asked the Minister for National Development what measures his Ministry has taken to shorten the development time for Housing and Development Board flats.

     Mr Koo Tsai Kee (for the Minister for National Development): Sir, over the years, HDB has introduced various measures to increase construction

Column: 939

productivity and hence shorten the development time for its flats. These measures include promoting "buildable" designs, encouraging greater use of pre-cast concrete components and site mechanisation. Through these measures, HDB has successfully improved the overall construction productivity. In fact, according to the CIDB's report, HDB's labour productivity in the year 1994 was three times that of the private residential sector and two times that of Singapore's overall construction productivity.

    Besides increasing construction productivity, HDB is also working very closely with contractors to improve site management so as to achieve better coordination of various activities and to reduce abortive works.

MONETARY AUTHORITY OF SINGAPORE
(Aid given to help Thai currency)


    4. Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Finance what was the aid given by the Monetary Authority of Singapore to help the Thai currency.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) assisted the Bank of Thailand by intervening jointly in the foreign exchange market to stabilise the value of the Thai baht on 14th May 1997 when the baht came under speculative attack. Like other central banks, the Bank of Thailand and MAS' officials consult regularly on central bank related matters. And the proceedings of these meetings and the details or market transactions are necessarily confidential to the authorities.

     Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, the Minister says it is confidential. May I know whether any loss was suffered as a result of this intervention? Or is that confidential?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: No, that is not confidential at all. No loss was suffered.

SPORTS AND RECREATION CENTRE IN
CHOA CHU KANG NEW TOWN


    5. Dr Teo Ho Pin asked the Minister for Community Development whether his Ministry will be developing any sports and recreation facilities (including swimming pool) for residents in Bukit Panjang area.

     The Minister for Community Development (Mr Abdullah Tarmugi): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member may be pleased to know that the Government will build a sports and recreation centre in Choa Chu Kang New Town. The Centre which will service the residents of Bukit Panjang and Choa Chu Kang New Towns is bounded by Choa Chu Kang North 5 and Choa Chu Kang Street 53. The two constituencies will be linked by a light rail system and residents from both areas will have easy access to the sports and recreation facilities.

    The sports and recreation centre will be an integrated sports complex comprising swimming pools, a multi-purpose stadium hall and an outdoor stadium.

    Construction of the centre is scheduled to start in November this year and the Centre is expected to be ready by the end of 1999. It will cost the Government $58.4 million.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (East Coast): Sir, today, the Government is adopting a more flexible approach towards the use of dialects in our mass media, ie, television and radio. The Minister for Information

Column: 941

and the Arts has clarified earlier that MITA will gradually relax its control over dialect television programmes by allowing the SCV to screen more dialect programmes. This is indeed a good move.

    TCS too has relaxed over the years, but to a very limited extent, the use of dialects in some of their programmes, particularly documentary progammes where they involve interviewing senior citizens and housewives who can only speak dialects. I think this is also a good move.

    Sir, I also agree that the Government has to strike a fine balance between keeping dialect programmes and promoting Mandarin. However, I believe that the interference of dialect in the learning of Mandarin today is no longer a serious threat as it was in the past. It is indeed no more a regressive step if we introduce dialects in our broadcast media.

    Sir, under our bilingual education, Chinese children study English and Chinese in school. They speak Mandarin or English at home, and indeed very few among our children today understand dialects.

    Sir, I am speaking on this topic on behalf of many senior citizens and housewives who do not understand a word of Mandarin today, and who do not speak a word of Mandarin. They only understand dialects. I think we need to reach out to this group of people, particularly in explaining Government policies and regulations to them. And there is no better way to do it than through dialects.

    One way to do this is to broadcast these programmes during off-peak hours, as one of my GPC Members, the hon. Dr Ho, mentioned yesterday, by screening these programmes during weekdays in the morning or afternoon, where viewership is restricted to housewives and senior citizens.

    Also, Sir, dialect programmes remind us of our history, our roots and our culture, which is a good way to preserve our culture and traditions. In essence, what I am proposing is that we could allow more room for dialect programmes on our television and radio so as to better

Column: 942

educate our growing number of senior citizens and housewives on Government policies and regulations, and to encourage the promotion of our roots and culture. This could help make our life to be more interesting and colourful, without changing our policy on the Speak Mandarin Campaign, or affecting the learning of the Chinese language.

     Mr Peh Chin Hua (Jalan Besar)( In Mandarin): Sir, I agree and support my GPC Chairman for MITA, Mr Chew Heng Ching, and my GPC colleague, Dr Ho Tat Kin's appeal to relax our control on dialect programmes.

    In Singapore nowadays, we still have a lot of senior citizens who could not understand either English or Mandarin. Every evening at 8 pm, these old folks are able to enjoy the news programme broadcast in different dialects. Although they have only a few minutes where they could receive this news in the various dialects, it gives them better understanding of our Government's policies and a sense of involvement, a sense of identity and feel that they have been looked after. Therefore, I suggest that MITA should increase the frequency of dialect programmes on radio, maybe once at 7 o'clock in the morning because senior citizens normally wake up very early and the young people will be busy preparing to go to work, and another at 2 o'clock in the afternoon, after lunch, which is usually the time when the old people will be relaxing. This way, they will be able to receive news in dialects and be updated on the latest development in Singapore so that they would not feel that they are detached from society.

    I understand that it may be difficult to get news readers who can read the news in dialects. But I think this is not a problem. If we are keen to provide dialect programmes for our senior citizens, we should be able to so something. We can seek the help of clan associations in Singapore like the Hokkien Huay Kuan, the Kong Chow Wiu Koon, the Hainanese Association, etc, to provide the people to read news in the dialects.

    I hope that MITA would seriously consider this. So long as it does not hinder our bilingual policy and Speak Mandarin Campaign, we should relax this control and have more dialect programmes on radio and TV.
12.45 pm

     Mr Seng Han Thong (Ang Mo Kio)( In Mandarin): Sir, I support what the Member for Jalan Besar has said, because right now there is only one dialect programme, ie, the 8 pm News dialect programme on Radio. It is only five minutes and the new is read very fast. Old people need time to think to follow the news.

    For the older Singaporeans, if they know only dialects and for some reasons, their children are unable to keep them informed of the latest happenings or Government policies in Singapore, the only source of information they get is from the dialect news programme. Of course, they may learn something from their chit-chats with other senior citizens at the void decks or hearsay from the market place. But this type of information may not be accurate. Because of that, they may not understand or may even misunderstand some of the policies which may be beneficial to them. For example recently in the Budget, the Finance Minister announced the topping-up of the Medisave account for senior citizens. They need to put in only $20 instead of $50 to enjoy the $100 to $350 top-up. Very few senior citizens know about this benefit. From the two top-up exercises that we carried out in the past, a lot of senior citizens were not aware of them. They did not know where and how to top up their CPF accounts, and lost out in the benefits which they would have gained.

    I would suggest that we should have one more round of dialect news over the Radio every day. I suggest that after
9.00 am, those people who are working would have gone to work and the students would have gone to school and these old people might just come back from their morning qiqong exercises. So in the late morning they have the time to listen to

Column: 944

the radio news. The Speak Mandarin campaign has achieved certain success and one extra dialect news programme will not hinder the progress of the Speak Mandarin campaign.

    In Singapore 21, the Prime Minister has said that one of the five pillars is to look after the senior citizens. The Minister for Finance also looks after the senior citizens because he announced the top-up of CPF Medisave Accounts. This is only material care for them. We need to give them more information and to understand what is happening to them. They need some spiritual care too. After corporatization, TCS programmes are always based on commercial consideration. This may not be wrong, but when we are talking about looking after the poor and the old, our broadcasting stations should also provide more pabulum to the senior citizens. As Mr Peh said, if you have problem getting news readers in dialect, you can seek the help of the clan associations failing which you can approach the interpreters or even go to the MPs like me for help.

     Mr R. Sinnakaruppan (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): Sir, satellites play an important role in today's telecommunications and broadcast industries. To encourage companies in Singapore to launch their own satellites, the Minister for Finance announced that the investment allowance incentive would be extended to satellite operators and that leasing of capacity on satellites operated by non-resident persons will be tax exempt.

    The Minister for Finance also mentioned that having our own satellites will enhance Singapore's competitiveness as a communications and media hub by extending our communications infrastructure beyond just submarine cables, land lines and TV broadcasting stations. He added that it will also allow service providers in Singapore to offer competitive packages to attract content creators, developers and distributors.

    The Government's Television Receive Only (TVRO) policy has always been to disallow the use of satellite dishes for households, so as to keep out harmful

Column: 945

satellite broadcasts which can convey values and lifestyles that are offensive to our multi-racial and multi-religious society.

    However, in recent years, two things have happened. One is that Internet and multi-media technology has opened up and this allows users to port in TV programmes from all over the world. The Government has also maintained an open and supportive attitude towards the Internet because of its commercial and international importance.

    Second, the satellite TV technology is improving by leaps and bounds. The satellite dish size which is determined by the frequency received by the dish and the satellite transmission power, is getting smaller and smaller. The satellite dish size is getting smaller and smaller. It is becoming more and more difficult to know if a household has set up a dish on its roof in other countries and also it may become possible to get a line-of-sight from within the house.

    Given these two realities, I would like to ask the Minister if the Government has any plans to review its TVRO policy to allow households to install such satellite dishes.

     Mr Peh Chin Hua (Jalan Besar)( In Mandarin): Sir, in last year's debate, I commented in this House that Internet has become more and more commonly and widely used in Singapore. At the same time, Internet has been misused by some abusers. For example, the spreading of pornographic materials, sexual notes, and some groundless political comments and misleading curt religious propaganda, etc. MITA has required all Internet users and Internet service providers to be registered and licensed so that we would have a better control on the development of Internet in Singapore to protect our moral standard, political stability and religious harmony. I do not know whether this control has been effective. I hope MITA would take strong measures to further strengthen the control of Internet in Singapore.

Column: 946



    E-mail is also part of Internet. It is widely used in commercial and financial activities and it has also become part of our daily lives. Of course, there are also pros and cons in E-mail because some people could make use of E-mail to communicate with their friends and some would use it to send some nonsensical articles or materials or even pornographic materials. Some people even use the E-mail to commit crimes. So long as we have a strict control on the abuse of Internet, I think the advantage of E-mail clearly outweighs its disadvantages. For example, by E-mail, we could communicate with our friends, relatives or our children who are overseas and it would also help to enhance the cohesion of our families. Children who are studying overseas could maintain a good link with their families. Now that the Government is encouraging people to venture overseas or to work overseas, E-mail will enable them to communicate with their family easily and effectively, and at the same time keep up with what is happening back home in Singapore. They will be able to understand the latest legislation and policies in Singapore. Therefore, I hope that MITA would give more publicity on the use of E-mail at home, because if all the families in Singapore could use E-mail, it would be of great advantage to our people. I think we should teach our people to learn how to use E-mail in their home.

     Dr Ho Tat Kin (Bishan-Toa Payoh): The introduction of the Internet Class Licence Scheme (CLS) last July was the first step to set up a regulatory framework for Internet in Singapore. However, with the use of proxy servers, Internet users continue to complain of slow access and the ISPs' reluctance to upgrade their equipment to increase transmission speed.

    Last August, the NIAC was formed to advise and give feedback to SBA on how to promote Internet development and fine-tune the regulations. As technology changes very rapidly, MITA must continue to review and assess the scope and focus of the regulatory framework to ensure that regulations and policy developments move in tandem with technology.

Column: 947



    Sir, one of the more important issues to consider now must be the safeguard of individual privacy on the Internet. The other concern which requires urgent attention is how to control gambling on the Internet. Sir, this morning's Straits Times carried an article "Internet gambling booms: `Ignorant' US authorities urged to regulate unstoppable trend." Sir, may I ask the Minister what measures would be taken to address these two issues of individual privacy and controlling of gambling on the Net? Sir, I would also like to ask the Minister what changes will be made to the CLS and how will the changes affect the Internet community.

    MITA should spare no effort to develop Singapore into an Internet hub for the region. We have the right infrastructure and the supporting technical people. To facilitate this development, MITA must ensure that our regulations do not inhibit the development of local web sites on the Internet. They must not be seen to be over-strict with censorship as this is still the perception. Users are reluctant to discuss Singapore issues in Soc.Culture.Singapore as they actually believe that MITA and the ISD will trace them if they say something bad about the PAP or the Government. So today we have more discussions on Singapore in Soc.Culture.Malaysia.

    Sir, the number of Internet subscribers in China is expected to jump by 100,000 to 250,000 by the end of 1997, as Chinese businessmen and families become more aware of the benefits of being able to access a network of global communication. As China opens up, there will eventually be a big Chinese Internet community. We have the advantage of a bilingual education. Singapore should also develop its Chinese language Internet capability in tandem with China's Internet development so that our Internet users will have the advantage of tapping on to another big network rich in information and resources. This will complement our development as a media hub. Sir, may I ask the Minister what efforts will he make towards this objective.

Column: 948



     Mr Ong Kian Min (Pasir Ris): Sir, I wish to support the Government's programme to have computers accessible to all our students. This is a step in the right direction as we enter the millennium where the acquisition of knowledge and its proper application will put Singapore at the cutting edge of progress and development. Whilst we encourage Singaporeans to access the information super highway, we are faced with a problem that will destroy the moral fibre of our society if we do not address the issue, and that is the question of pornography on the Internet.

    Over the years, this House has debated at length the prohibition of satellite dishes for households and control over what comes into our homes through the air. I believe, Sir, that the Internet, if not regulated properly, poses a danger of greater magnitude because of how it is weaving its way into our daily lives. Surfing the Internet can bring us effortlessly or even accidentally face to face with pornography, fraud, gambling, sedition and other distasteful topics. It is also common knowledge that information transmitted through the Internet are merely bits and bytes and therefore even with the use of electronic filters, comprehensive blockage of undesirable materials coming through cyberspace, it is impossible without, in the process, filtering out materials which the public has the right to see.

    Nevertheless, this Government has opted for the use of proxy server as a means of control. Having decided on this option, I believe that it is in our interest to make it effective. I share Mr Peh's concern that the present controls are not as effective as it should be. An ineffective proxy server can be counter productive because parents may mistakenly believe that the proper controls have been set up by the Government and hence they can dedicate less care and attention to what their children are viewing on line. If the proxy server is not effective, then we should openly admit so and encourage parents to either use a software fix of their choice or resort to the old fashioned solution or supervising their kids' time on line. However, I am sure that if we want to,

Column: 949

we can make the proxy server more effective. In the longer term, we should look at the development and use of content rating software. In the near term, before the perfection of such software, the appropriate resources must be committed to manually identifying these undesirable websites and blocking access to them.

    In the area of conventional films and video tapes, I understand the Board of Film Censors has 16 full-time censors who went through more than four-and-a-half million pieces of films and video tapes last year. If full-time staff cannot be dedicated for the purposes of the Internet, perhaps the finder's reward system can be started under which Internet surfers who give information leading to the blockage of undesirable websites can be rewarded with a small memento. But if for the technical reasons I mentioned earlier, we take the approach that censorship of the Internet cannot be carried out effectively on a national level, then at the very least, protection should be accorded to our children.

    The Internet is like a television with 100 channels - 80 with good educational programmes and 20 channels with undesirable contents. Our children are encouraged to use the Internet for its educational benefits. But they can easily at any time while surfing the Internet, at the mere click of the mouse, switch to the undesirable channels that bring them straight into the red light district. I am advocating that in the process of connecting every school in Singapore to the Net, we must put in place some way of making the Internet safe for our children. To do this, all schools, colleges and libraries should be connected to the Ministry of Education server, which must be beefed up to add as an Internet Service Provider to serve their needs for access to the Internet. This Ministry of Education server must then enforce the highest standards of decency so that offensive materials may be kept away from our children.

     Dr Yaacob Ibrahim (Jalan Besar): Sir, National Education has been given a lot of importance lately. Many Members of the House have spoken about the need for us to remind the younger generation and succeeding generations about how this country came about. I suggested during the debate on the Budget Statement that the Government consider setting up a fund to attract private groups to participate in the promotion of National Education. The Finance Minister replied that National Education will be disseminated through the schools and that private groups can be roped into the development of materials. I welcome this move. However, the NE programme in schools will only have an impact on school-going children and teens. I am concerned about the availability of NE programmes aimed at the general public. I understand MITA will undertake a variety of projects, including staging exhibitions at the museums to promote NE. Perhaps the Minister may want to enlighten us further on other initiatives being taken by MITA.

    I would also like to suggest that perhaps MITA consider my suggestion of setting up a fund. MITA has in fact successfully drawn private groups into a variety of public-related projects, for example, the Arts Festival. In a similar manner, I wonder whether MITA could consider tapping the resources and expertise of private groups and organisations in its effort to promote National Education. For NE to become successful, and, in this instance, I would define success as taking place when the sense of being a Singaporean is present in almost everyone, NE projects would have to be carried out across all sections of society. These projects need to reach out to the young, the not-so-old and the old. But the approach for each of these groups cannot be the same. A variety of presentations is needed. This is where I believe that private groups and organisations can offer a multitude of approaches appealing to different audience groups. It is also equally important to tell the story of Singapore without arousing emotions and even suspicions among the different races. This is not an easy task. For

Column: 951

example, how can we tell the story of Maria Hertogh and its attendant lessons without rousing emotions? Can the events associated with Maria Hertogh be presented in a popular medium such as a musical? In the recently concluded Festival of Asian Performing Arts, the Shiki Theatrical Company of Japan staged a musical entitled Ri Koran. I understand the Minister actually attended the performance. This play is based on a true story of a Japanese girl, born and raised in China, who became a star in several Japanese propaganda movies made during World War II. Although the material was highly controversial, the musical has been well received in both Japan and China. Hence, I believe that efforts by private groups in showcasing our history, though difficult, can be done successfully.

    Sir, National Education should also be about popularising symbols, stories, songs, poems and other activities associated with this country such that it becomes embedded in our psyche. My GPC Chairman, Mr Chew Heng Ching, lamented that not many Singaporeans would recite the National Anthem when it is being played. DPM BG Lee Hsien Loong, during the launch of NE, cited two examples of strong nationalistic pride: the Americans and Japanese. The Americans, for example, are proud of their anthem and they know the words very well. This comes about because the anthem is played at every major sporting event in the country. Before the start of the baseball World Series or the Superbowl, popular singers will be invited to sing the anthem. In Japan, on the other hand, history buffs would stage key historical events of the country for the public to view and learn. And they do this, as I understand, at their own expense. In other words, the symbols, songs, history and other associated materials are brought down to the general level for all to appreciate and understand. I believe such efforts must be spearheaded by MITA but with private groups contributing in that effort. Hence, the need for a fund for National Education.

Column: 952

    In America, if you subscribe to a TV cable package, you probably get one or two Chinese channels. But those are ghetto channels. It will always be different from Channel 5 because our society, as seen through the eyes of the Chinese-educated and the Chinese-speaking, will always be different from the way it is seen by someone who is English-educated, or by a Malay or an Indian. In the same way, when one tunes to Channel 8, one should have a sense that this is also Singapore, although seen from a slightly different perspective.     In fact, I was very touched by Mr Choo Wee Khiang's comment yesterday about the way our TV stations carried the Hong Kong handover. I was not in Singapore at that time. I was in Hong Kong. But because it was a very important event,

Column: 971

when I came back, I took pains to get feedback from various people in different walks of life on their responses to the Hong Kong handover. For Chinese all over the world, it was a very emotional event, even a spiritual event. Not surprisingly, because the Opium War, the Treaty of Nanjing, began a train of events in China which eventually forced many of our forefathers to migrate to Southeast Asia and to Singapore. After migrating here, the emotions, the hatred, the sense of humiliation, continued to be nursed and passed down. Naturally, this is more strongly felt by Chinese Singaporeans and even more so by Chinese-educated Singaporeans.

    In fact, till today, I have not met a single adult Chinese Singaporean who did not stay up that night to watch the handover till 12.30 am. It must have been, in the history of broadcasting in Singapore, one of the most watched events ever on television on both Channel 5 and Channel 8. That Channel 5 coverage should be different from Channel 8 coverage is also very natural. If they were the same, something is wrong. They have had many good background programmes in the run up to 30th June, both on Channel 5 and Channel 8, but not on Channel 12, because there the audiences are mainly Malay and Tamil and we would not expect our Malay and Indian compatriots to have the same degree of interest in the handover of Hong Kong back to China. But all take a Singaporean viewpoint, and it is very important that we take a Singaporean viewpoint. We just cannot take the feed from Hong Kong.

    In fact, when I was in Hong Kong watching television, I took care to switch channels, now BBC, now CNN, Chinese television, Hong Kong television, in order to get a sense of how the perspective changed from different angles. Someone I met told me that he met Dan Rather from CBS at a hotel lobby in Hong Kong and Rather complained that there was nothing to report about. "There is nothing to report about," he said, because he was looking for other things. He was not looking at the main event. Indeed, if you watch CNN and, to some extent, BBC, the

Column: 972

event was presented as something to be sad about, to be worried about. Whereas if you tuned on to Chinese television, it was something to be celebrated.

    We should neither take the American position nor the Chinese position. We should take our own position, reflecting our own history, reflecting where our forefathers came from, reflecting our own political situation in Southeast Asia. On their own, the TV stations decided - Channels 5 and 8 - to carry it live, which I think was a correct decision. That TV12 did not carry it live was also a correct decision, in the same way as our neighbouring countries did not carry it live on their television stations. But that Channels 5 and 8 should carry it, I think, reflected the standpoints of many Singaporeans and it was the right thing to do.

    This event is also important because it highlights a key difficulty in the promotion of heritage in Singapore. Life is not vanilla flavoured or monochromatic. Life is full of colour, full of smells, full of flavours. And it should be like that. It is in the combination that the meal is to be enjoyed. But, of course, the flavours and the sounds should not be so clashing that it destroys the meal. This is what we should try to do when we deal with sensitive issues concerning heritage in Singapore.

    Some comments on Singapore Cable Vision. The objective here is not really the profitability of SCV which is a private

Column: 976

company. The objective here is really Singapore One, IT 2000, and preparing our people for the future. What we want eventually is to remove bandwidth as a constraint in our life in Singapore. What does this mean? This means that eventually at home, in the office, broadband into every room, into every bathroom, into every kitchen, because terminal equipment will become cheaper and simpler. It may not even require human intervention. But once we have broadband into every room, all kinds of appliances, all kinds of devices become possible and it is that kind of a world which we should be preparing ourselves for in Singapore. And this is really what the whole objective of cabling is about.

    This 14% penetration now is not too bad. It will grow, which is the experiences in most countries. We are over-60% wired now. By the end of next year, most of the island should be wired. Certainly all those who live in apartment blocks, and 90% of those living in landed properties.

    On Internet, it is still very early. It is a whole new frontier being tamed. It will take many years. Many debates all over the world, what we are discussing here is similar to what is taking place in every country on the face of this earth. There are reports from the White House, there are reports from governments conferring in Europe. They are discussing this in ASEAN. Our approach is very simple. Where it involves broadcasting, which means a limited number of sites, SBA will regulate it. Hence, stations with mass impact, on religion, on politics, hate sites. Where it is more in the realm of private communication, then we regulate it like we would the postal service, or the fax machine, or the telephone line, which means safeguarding privacy, not allowing crimes to be committed, and from time to time, conducting sting operations. If you are collecting money from purveying pornography in Singapore, we will catch you eventually. If you are defrauding consumers, we will catch up with you. If you are promoting gambling and not paying your taxes, we will find a way to catch up with you, and eventually the tax collector will also want to have his cut on the Internet.

Column: 977



    So these are issues which are still on the boil. We are keeping up with what regulatory agencies in other countries are doing and making sure that what we do is in tandem with what they are doing. Because if only we are doing it, we will fail. Proxy servers are not to censor. Proxy servers are to overcome the constraint of bandwidth in and out of Singapore. We create these information reservoirs so that, with relatively small pipes coming in and out of Singapore, the information coming in can be gathered, stored in reservoirs, in order to increase the speed of Internet access by Singaporeans. And once we move onto broadband Internet, Internet will be much faster and will be greatly promoted.

    I share Mr Peh Chin Hua's point of view that we should promote E-mail and we should also promote, as Dr Ho Tat Kin said, Chinese Internet. In fact, Chinese Internet is very important. We have many discussions with Chinese authorities. They have been looking at how we regulate Internet in Singapore. Their objective is eventually to create their own Chinese cyberuniverse, because they have a very high barrier to entry, which is the Chinese language. They are proliferating TCP/IP all over China and creating huge numbers of websites. If we as a city, from the cyberspace point of view, are part of both the Anglo-Saxon universe and the Chinese universe, then we have a great advantage. And it is an advantage which is not easy for others to take away from us because language is a very high barrier to entry. And what we must do is to encourage young Singaporeans, while their minds are still malleable and their fingers are still tactile, for them to learn to input in Chinese, learn to access Chinese Internet, so that when they grow up, they are as familiar in the Chinese Internet universe as they are in the English universe. Then we tap two huge reservoirs and this will give us a great advantage over many other cities.

    It is an advantage which we can have because of our bilingual policy and we should not waste time, because every generation that is lost will be lost forever. It is very difficult to master these things as adults because different parts of the brain

Column: 978

have to be called into operation, and we are just not as good. If we watch young children handling the Internet, they can click the mouse faster than we can blink. So you either master these skills when you are young or you can only master them very imperfectly when you grow older. Our objective is eventually to have every Singaporean, in addition to his postal address, also his own Internet postal address, his e-mail address, and for many Singaporeans to be able to access equally, both English Internet and Chinese Internet.

But once it is clearer what are those which are available, we may require our Internet Service Access Providers (ISAPs) to make them available to parents. But, of course, always at a cost, because if you block out too many websites, then it affects the efficiency of your own normal Internet. But if parents feel that it is necessary and they are prepared to bear with that certain decline in quality, then let parents decide. And what we do as regulators is to require the ISAPs to eventually provide such options to parents. I do not think we are quite ready yet because while many software packages are available, they do not work very well. But I think we will see good progress in the coming one or two years. And once it is ripe enough, we will require the ISAPs to provide such a menu of choices for parents.

He knew what he was talking about and we should listen to him seriously.     Before I report on the Committee's recommendations, permit me to reiterate the reasons for a mandatory minimum retirement age and the need to raise it beyond the present 60 years of age. With increasing life expectancy and declining birth rates, our population is ageing rapidly. As the GPC Chairman for Labour noted moments ago, currently, eight economically-active persons support one aged person who is 60 years and above. In fact, if we project this in the years ahead, the number of economically-active persons supporting one aged person will decline sharply. In 1988, the Government set a 3-year time frame for companies to voluntarily raise the retirement age of their employees to 60 years. But progress was slow.     Sir, after thorough deliberations of the issues connected to retirement age, and taking into consideration the views and concerns of both the employers and unions, the Tripartite Committee has made seven key recommendations.

    First, the Committee recommends that the statutory minimum retirement age be raised from 60 to 62 with effect from 1st January 1999. The 18-month notice period from now till the end of 1998 will give employers, workers and unions sufficient time to make the necessary adjustments. The Committee also recommends that further extension of the retirement age should depend on the prevailing economic circumstances and also the experience gained from this adjustment.

    Second, employers retaining older workers beyond the age of 60 should be allowed to reduce wage cost by adopting the following cost-cutting measures:-

    (a) A reduction in employers' CPF contributions from 7.5% to 4% in respect of employees between the age of 60 and 65; and from 5% to 4% in respect of employees above the age of 65;

    (b) Employers should be given the discretion under the Retirement Age Act to reduce the wage cost of employees above the age of 60 by up to 10%. The reduction could be effected through a cut in basic wage or a combination of wage cost items including fringe benefits, variable bonus, AWS, and basic wage and a reduction in working hours.

    The 10% cut in wage costs would be over and above the reduction in employers' CPF contributions.

    Third, the service period for computation of retrenchment benefit be capped at 25 years. Based on the current norm in the payment of retrenchment benefit, the cap would mean that a retrenched worker who had worked for 25 years or more in a company would be paid between 1 and 2 years of salary as retrenchment benefit. This amount of payment should be sufficient to see him through the period of looking for alternative employment.

    Fourth, employers are encouraged to adopt the Base-Up Wage System in place of the current Seniority-Based Wage System. The inherent weakness of the Seniority-Based Wage System is the wide gap between the minimum and maximum salary. As a result, the salary structure does not reflect the actual value of the job. This will hamper the employment of older workers and cause wages to be uncompetitive as the workforce ages. The Seniority-Based Wage System also demotivates younger workers who are doing the same job for a much less pay. The adoption of the Base-Up Wage System will narrow the minimum and maximum salary ratio and enable wage increases to be more closely linked to productivity growth. It will also ensure that the wage structure would better reflect the value of the job.
